AIRCZ Type:: Gatwick Airport Wind Turbine Consultation Zone:Contact: The Safeguarding Department, Gatwick Airport Limited, 7th Floor Destinations Place, London Gatwick Airport, West Sussex, RH06 0NP

description: Demolition of existing detached dwelling and erection of 2no. two storey semi-detached dwellings with attic.
decision_conditions: The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.Reason: This is required by Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990.

Notwithstanding the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as amended) (or any Order revoking and reenacting that Order with or without modification), no windows shall be inserted nor any other openings formed (other than those expressly authorised by this permission) at first floor level or above in the in the northern (flank) or southern (flank) elevations of the dwellings unless otherwise agreed in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Notwithstanding the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as amended) (or any Order revoking and reenacting that Order with or without modification), no additions or enlargements to any dwellinghouse(s) on the site (other than those expressly authorised by this permission) shall be erected unless otherwise agreed in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, evidence showing that the development has achieved at least a 19% improvement in CO2 emissions versus Part L of the Building Regulations and internal water usage rates of no greater than 105L per person per day have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: In the interests of sustainability and energy conservation, in accordance with policy 5.2 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS1, DM3 and DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, a detailed hard and soft landscaping scheme shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The approved scheme shall be implemented within the first planting season following substantial completion of the development. The tree planting and landscaping shall thereafter be maintained for five years to the satisfaction of the Local Planning Authority. Any trees or shrubs which die during this period shall be replaced during the following planting season, and the areas shown to be landscaped shall be permanently retained for that purpose.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development, in accordance with policies 7.4 and 7.6 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, details of any walls, gates, fences or other means of enclosure to be erected on the site shall be submitted to and agreed in writing by the local planning authority. These details shall also show how the land on the site will be apportioned between the approved dwellings as private outdoor amenity space. The development shall then be carried out in strict accordance with the approved details and permanently retained as such thereafter.Reason: In the interests of ensuring a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development and to ensure satisfactory living conditions for future occupants of the development and neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to the commencement of any development above ground level, details of waste and recycling facilities to serve the development to which this permission relates shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The refuse and recycling facilities as shown in the approved details shall be provided prior to beneficial occupation of the development and shall be permanently retained thereafter. The developer and/or their successors in title shall take all reasonable steps to ensure that all refuse and recyclable materials associated with the development are either stored within these facilities or internally within the building(s) on the application site, and that no refuse or recycling material is stored or placed for collection on the public highway except on the day of collection.Reason: To ensure proper waste management in the interests of the character and appearance of the area and the living conditions of neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policies 5.17 and 7.4 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to the commencement of any development above ground level, details of secure cycle parking facilities to serve the development to which this permission relates shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority.The cycle parking facilities as shown in the approved details shall be provided prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates and shall be permanently retained for that purpose and kept free from obstruction thereafter.Reason: To ensure that appropriate opportunities to promote sustainable transport are taken up, in accordance with policy 6.9 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS6 and DM8 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The garaging or car parking shown on the approved plans shall be provided with a hard-bound, adequately-drained, dust-free surface prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates and shall be permanently retained and kept free from obstruction thereafter. It shall not be used for any purposes other than the parking of vehicles for the occupiers of and visitors to the development.Reason: To ensure the provision of adequate off-street parking in the interests of the safety and operation of the highway network, in accordance with policy 6.13 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS7 and DM9 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, the vehicular crossover(s) as shown on the approved plans shall be provided (including reinstating the footway to the satisfaction of the local planning authority) and shall be permanently retained for that purpose and kept free from obstruction thereafter.Reason: To ensure proper vehicular access to the site in the interests of the safety and operation of the highway network, in accordance with policies 6.3 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS6 and DM8 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

No development shall take place (including any works of demolition) until a construction management plan or construction method statement has been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The approved plan/statement shall be adhered to throughout the construction period. The statement shall provide for:i) How the proposed development will be built;ii) Hours of working (which shall be limited to 08.00 to 18.00 Mondays to Fridays and between 08.00 to 13.00 on Saturdays and not at all on Bank Holidays and Sundays);iii) The procedure for loading/unloading materials;iv) The route to and away from site for muck away and vehicles with materials;v) The protocol for managing deliveries to one vehicle at a time on sites with restricted access or space;vi) The protocol for managing vehicles that need to wait for access to the site; vii) Whether any reversing manoeuvres are required onto or off the public highway into the site and whether a banksman will be provided;viii) Temporary site access;ix) Signing system for works traffic;x) Whether site access warning signs will be required in adjacent roads;xi) Whether it is anticipated that statutory undertaker connections will be required into the site;xii) The storage of plant, materials and operatives vehicles;xiii) The potential for impacts from dust and emissions during the demolition and/or construction phase upon local air quality and surrounding residents;xiv) Measures for the laying of dust, suppression of noise and abatement of other nuisance arising from development works;xv) The location of all ancillary site buildings;xvi) The means of enclosure of the site, its erection and maintenance;xvii) Wheel washing equipment;xviii) The parking of vehicles of site operatives and visitors.xix) Meeting the requirements of the Low Emission Zone for Non-Road Mobile Machinery (where relevant plant or vehicles are being used)xx) The method of recycling and disposing of waste resulting from the demolition and/or construction phasesDeliveries/collections to and from the site shall use a route that is agreed with the highway authority and the agreed route shall be signed accordingly.Reason: In order to safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and in the interests of the safety and operation of the highway network, in accordance with policy 6.13 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS7 and DM9 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.These details are required prior to commencement of development because the relevant works would take place at the beginning of the construction phase.

In the event that contamination is found (at any time) that was not previously identified, development shall cease and the contamination reported in writing to the local planning authority as soon as is reasonably practicable. An assessment, remediation scheme and verification report shall then be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority before development resumes.Reason: To ensure that risks from land contamination are minimised, in accordance with policy 5.21 of the London Plan 2016 and policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to above ground works details of the implementation, adoption, maintenance and management of a sustainable drainage system have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The system shall be implemented prior to occupation and thereafter managed and maintained in accordance with the approved details. Those details shall include a timetable for its implementation, and a management and maintenance plan for the lifetime of the development which shall include the arrangements for adoption by any public body or statutory undertaker, or any other arrangements to secure the effective operation of the sustainable drainage system throughout its lifetime.Reason: In order to prevent the increased risk of flooding in accordance with Policy CS1 (Climate Change Mitigation) of the Local Development Framework Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to the commencement of any development above ground level, a sample of the facing materials to be utilised in the development to which this permission relates shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The development shall then be carried out in strict accordance with the approved samples.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development, in accordance with policies 7.4 and 7.6 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, any windows or rooflights at first floor level or above in the northern (flank) and southern (flank) elevations shall be constructed so that no part of the framework less than 1.7m above finished floor level shall be openable. Any part below that level shall be fitted with and permanently retained in obscure glazing to a minimum of level 3 on the standard scale. Any film used to achieve the requisite obscurity level shall be non-perishable, tamper-proof, and shall be replaced immediately in the event that it ceases to result in obscurity to level 3.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.
A1 - Loading

The applicant is informed that the submitted details for Condition 6 (Facing Materials) of planning permission 19/01259/FUL has been assessed by relevant consultants and is hereby approved subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the approved details.

The application is made pursuant to Section 96A of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended), which concerns non-material amendments to planning permission.Under Section 96A, a change may be made to any planning permission, including through the imposition of new conditions or the removal/alteration of existing conditions, if the local planning authority is satisfied that the change is not material. In deciding whether a change is material, a local planning authority must have regard to the effect of the change, together with any previous changes made under this section, on the planning permission as originally granted.The National Planning Practice Guidance states that there is no statutory definition of 'non-material'. This is because it will be dependent on the context of the overall scheme - an amendment that is non-material in one context may be material in another. The judgement on 'materially' in any particular case is one of fact and degree.The application seeks to amend Condition 2 (Approved Plans) of planning permission 20/01216/FUL (allowed on appeal-ref. APP/Z5630/W/20/3260562) to reflect the installation of x12 solar panels on the roof.

The application is made pursuant to Section 96A of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended), which concerns non-material amendments to planning permission.Under Section 96A, a change may be made to any planning permission, including through the imposition of new conditions or the removal/alteration of existing conditions, if the local planning authority is satisfied that the change is not material. In deciding whether a change is material, a local planning authority must have regard to the effect of the change, together with any previous changes made under this section, on the planning permission as originally granted.The National Planning Practice Guidance states that there is no statutory definition of 'non-material'. This is because it will be dependent on the context of the overall scheme - an amendment that is non-material in one context may be material in another. The judgement on 'materially' in any particular case is one of fact and degree.The application seeks to amend Condition 2 (Approved Plans) of planning permission 20/01216/FUL (allowed on appeal-ref. APP/Z5630/W/20/3260562) to reflect the installation of x12 solar panels on the roof.

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.It is not subject to any particular policy designations or environmental constraints.8 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and 1 objection has been received relating to:-the height and bulk of the building; and,- loss of light/sunlight. The concerns raised will be taken into consideration during the assessment of the application and detailed below.The key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings. DesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: While the proposed two storey rear extension would not strictly adhere to the recommendations set out in the Residential Design SPD, 2013 in terms of set down from the ridge of the original roofslope and set in from the shared boundary, it would have an appropriate roof form and would appear in keeping with the principal side and rear elevation of the property. Furthermore, it would not be visible from the street and would be finished in appropriate materials. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts in terms of character or appearance as a result of the proposed development. AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment:  While the proposed extension would only be separated from the shared boundary with neighbouring property No. 66 Malden Hill by approximately 0.6m, as stated above it would be in keeping with the existing principal side and rear elevations. Therefore, it would not adversely affect the amenities of No. 66 Malden Hill by reason of overbearing appearance or loss of light to principal habitable room windows. While additional openings are proposed facing No. 66 Malden Hill at first and second floor level, it is considered possible to mitigate any loss of privacy/overlooking by ensuring that they would be obscure-glazed and non-opening below 1.7m above finished floor levels in the event of an approval. However, this approach could only be taken in relation to secondary windows that didn't relate to habitable rooms.Given the separation distance between the proposed extension and No. 70 Malden Hill, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of No. 70 Malden Hill.In terms of ensuring good standards of amenity and accommmodation for existing and future occupants of the development site, it is considered that obscuring the principal window of the middle bedroom located on the first floor would result in a complete loss of outlook, which is unacceptable.  Further and in the absence of a proposed section plan, it is considered that the applicant has failed to demonstrarte that the two bedrooms at second floor level would benefit from adequate levels of outlook. It is also unclear whether these rooms would benefit from adequate levels of light.In conclusion, the proposed development would not be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The assessment of this application has been based on measurements taken from the submitted drawings / plans. If it transpires that the drawings / plans submitted are incorrect this would nullify this decision and you are advised to submit a fresh application with the correct information / drawings. If you carry out development based on incorrect plans you may be liable to the Council taking enforcement action against you.

In dealing with the application the Council has implemented the requirement in the National Planning Policy Framework to work with the applicant in a positive and proactive way.  We have made available detailed advice in the form or our statutory policies in the Core Strategy, Supplementary Planning Documents, Planning Briefs and other informal written guidance, as well as offering a full pre-application advice service, in order to ensure that the applicant has been given every opportunity to submit an application which is likely to be considered favourably.

The assessment of this application is based on measurements taken from the submitted drawings / plans. If it transpires that the drawings / plans submitted are incorrect this would nullify the validity of this decision and you are advised to submit a fresh application with the correct information / drawings.

--- Officer Report ---IntroductionThis application is of a nature where the Council's Constitution delegates the authority to make the decision to Officers rather than it being decided by a Committee of Councillors.  Before preparing this summary report a Planning Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the relevant Development Plan policies and guidance, considered any relevant previous planning applications, and considered any comments made by those interested in the application such as consultees with specialist knowledge and nearby residents. By indicating that the development proposal complies with relevant Development Plan policies, the planning officer is taking into account the information submitted with the application, any previous relevant applications, any comments received in connection with the application and any other case specific considerations which are material to the decision.The Development Plan comprises:The London Plan 2021;RBK Core Strategy 2012;Kingston Town Centre Area Action Plan 2008; and,The South London Waste Plan 2012.This decision has been authorised by a Senior Officer (Authorising Officer) in the Development Management Service. Prior to endorsing the Planning Officer's recommendation, the Authorising Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the application documents, the relevant planning policies and guidance, any relevant history, and any representations received.Application SiteThe site comprises emplyment land and premises (MOT Centre).Proposal Demolition of existing MOT garage building and erection of replacement two storey, 3 bedroom dwelling house (with roofspace accommodation) and refuse and cycle provisionConsultation:Two objections received and summarised as follows- Excessive height or bulk of buildings- Inadequate landscaping/means of enclosure- Inappropriate design/layout- Loss of light/Sunlight- Noise- PrivacyOfficer comment matters raised in the objection assessed in the assessment below.Pollution control officer no objection.Relevant history 18/12752/FUL Demolition of existing MOT garage building and erection of a (replacement) two storey, 3 bedroom dwelling house (with roofspace accommodation) Permitted with conditionsAssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- Loss of employment- Hosuing Supply-Standard of accommodation- Design of the proposed development; and,- Impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.- Highways- Fire safetyLoss of employment: Policy DM17 seeks to protect all employment land and premises in the borough. The applicant has failed to provide any marketing evidence to justify the loss of employment use of the site and as such the proposal would be contrary to policy DM17 of the Council's adopted Core Strategy.Housing supplyThe proposal would provide a family sized unit a net increase of one residential unit on the site. The Council does not have a 5 year housing supply and the proposal would help contribute to the Borough's London Plan target (policy H1 table 4.1) for year on year housing of 964 new homes a year for the 10 year period from 2021.  This is given weight in the overall consideration of the proposal as per paragraph 11 (d) of the NPPF. Standard of accommodation The proposed development would meet the minimum internal (90 sqm) and external (50 sqm (+5sqm per additional bedroom above 3 beds amenity space) space standards as set out in the London Plan Policy D6 table 3.1 and the Council's residential Design SPD.  DesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS) (2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.HighwaysThe applicant has failed to demonstrate by way of a parking beat survey that the development would not result in an increase in on street parking pressures and in turn lead to congestion and prejudice highway safety and in the absence of any off-street parking or a signed and completed legal agreement preventing future occupants and visitors from applying from on street parking permits to mitigate any potential on street parking pressures the proposed development would not accord with paragraph 111 of the NPPF and policies 6.1 of the London Plan and policies DM9 and DM10 of the Council's adopted LDF Core Strategy April 2012.Fire safetyThe application is not supported by any detail as to the future occupants fire safety and as such the proposal would not accord with policy D12 of the London Plan 2021.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is not considered to be in accordance with the development plan and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than the proposal is not in accordance with the development plan. Details of the Application SubmissionIn accordance with the requirements of Local Government Act 1972 details of the application submission were available on the Council's website during the assessment of the application.https://www.kingston.gov.uk/info/200155/planning_applications_and_permissions/263/find_a_planning_application_or_appeal

The application is made pursuant to Section 96A of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended), which concerns non-material amendments to planning permission. Under Section 96A, a change may be made to any planning permission, including through the imposition of new conditions or the removal/alteration of existing conditions, if the local planning authority is satisfied that the change is not material. In deciding whether a change is material, a local planning authority must have regard to the effect of the change, together with any previous changes made under this section, on the planning permission as originally granted.The National Planning Practice Guidance states that there is no statutory definition of 'non-material'. This is because it will be dependent on the context of the overall scheme - an amendment that is non-material in one context may be material in another. The judgement on 'materially' in any particular case is one of fact and degree.The application seeks the following amendments to planning permission reference: 19/02482/FUL:- Layout changes to the semi-detached houses to the rear of the siteThe proposed changes represent minor alterations to the layouts of the ground and first floor internal accommodation of the two semi-detached dwellinghouses to the rear of No's 318-320 Ewell Road. The proposed alterations would see the ground floor have a self-contained reception room to the front, with open plan kitchen/dining room to the rear. A ground floor wc and storage cupboards would be retained at ground floor. At first floor, the layout has been reconfigured slightly to allow for an en-suite to be added to the master bedroom. Dedicated cupboard storage would remain. The rear window to the bathroom would be slightly larger than that originally consented. The proposed changes do not harmfully impact upon room sizes which comply with technical space standards and all habitable rooms would continue to be provided with windows. There are no changes proposed to window and door placements (aside from the slight enlargement of the rear window at first floor serving the family bathrooms which would continue to be obscure-glazed) or external materiality or layout of the dwellinghouses from that as originally approved. Officers consider it necessary to carry across the condition regarding the need for obscure-glazing to the enlarged family bathroom windows and reapply to this non-material amendment application.Officers consider the proposals would not result in a material harmful effect on the layout of the dwellings, nor have a detrimental impact to the amenity afforded to the future occupants. Officers are similarly satisfied that the proposed amendments would not give rise to any material issues in terms of character and appearance of the development from the streetscene or to neighbouring amenities. Accordingly, the proposed amendment is considered to be non-material and it is recommended that the application be granted.

The applicant is informed that the submitted details, as set out above, are agreed and that the Planning Condition 4 (Construction Management Plan) of planning permission 19/01259/FUL is hereby discharged subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the details hereby approved. The applicant is advised to contact the RBK Streetworks Department to agree on traffic management arrangements prior to starting work. The applicant should also arrange with RBK Highways Inspections for a highway condition survey to be undertaken prior to commencement.

The assessment of this application is based on measurements taken from the submitted drawings / plans. If it transpires that the drawings / plans submitted are incorrect this would nullify the validity of this decision and you are advised to submit a fresh application with the correct information / drawings.

Application Site        The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling and falls within the Berg Estate Local Area of Special Character. ProposalErection of single-storey front porch extension.Consultation11x neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received. AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The impact of the proposed development on character and design and heritage; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- Car parking.Character, Design and HeritagePolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Paragraphs 199 to 208 of the NPPF 2021 set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements.Paragraph 203 states that the effect of an application on the significance of a non-designated heritage asset should be taken into account in determining any application. In weighing applications that directly or indirectly affect non-designated heritage assets, a balanced judgement is required, having regard to the scale of any harm or loss and the significance of the heritage asset.Officer Comment: Policy Guidance 38 of the Residential Design SPD 2013, provides guidance for the building of front extensions, including porches. The front porch extension would reflect the character of the main house, and other porch additions in the immediate area. In terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design, it is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.As stated above, Officers have concluded that there would be no adverse impact upon character and appearance. It follows that Officers consider that the proposed development would not result in any harm to the significance of the Berg Estate LASC.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Car ParkingPolicy T6 of the London Plan 2021 states that car parking should be restricted in line with levels of existing and future public transport accessibility and connectivity. The maximum standards as set out in policies T6.1 to T6.5 should be applied to development proposals. Where provided, each motorcycle parking space should count towards the maximum for car parking spaces at all use classes.Policy DM9, Policy DM10 and the Council's Sustainable Transport SPD 2013 together require development proposals to comply with the car parking standards in the London Plan.Officer Comment: The introduction of a front porch extension, would still allow the parking off street of at least one car. Therefore the proposal would comply with the Policy DM9 and DM10 of the Core Strategy and Policy T6 of the London Plan 2021.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

Application Site        The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling and falls within the Tudor Estate Local Area of Special Character. ProposalErection of single-storey front infill extension in line with existing porch. Associated changes to fenestrationConsultation14x neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received. AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The impact of the proposed development on character and design and heritage; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- Car parking.Character, Design and HeritagePolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Paragraphs 199 to 208 of the NPPF 2021 set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements.Paragraph 203 states that the effect of an application on the significance of a non-designated heritage asset should be taken into account in determining any application. In weighing applications that directly or indirectly affect non-designated heritage assets, a balanced judgement is required, having regard to the scale of any harm or loss and the significance of the heritage asset.Officer Comment: Policy Guidance 38 of the Residential Design SPD 2013, provides guidance for the building of front extensions, including porches. The single-storey front infill extension would reflect the character of the main house and would appear subordinate to the existing house. In terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design, it is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.As stated above, Officers have concluded that there would be no adverse impact upon character and appearance. It follows that Officers consider that the proposed development would not result in any harm to the significance of the Tudor Estate LASC.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Car ParkingPolicy T6 of the London Plan 2021 states that car parking should be restricted in line with levels of existing and future public transport accessibility and connectivity. The maximum standards as set out in policies T6.1 to T6.5 should be applied to development proposals. Where provided, each motorcycle parking space should count towards the maximum for car parking spaces at all use classes.Policy DM9, Policy DM10 and the Council's Sustainable Transport SPD 2013 together require development proposals to comply with the car parking standards in the London Plan.Officer Comment: The introduction of a single-storey front infill extension, would still allow the parking off street of at least two cars. Therefore the proposal would comply with the Policy DM9 and DM10 of the Core Strategy and Policy T6 of the London Plan 2021.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

Please submit a copy of an Ordnance Survey based site location plan scaled 1:1250 with the application site outlined in red and adjoining land owned by applicant in blue, showing at least two road frontages and a North point.The submitted location plan does not have two roads.
